I use emojis everywhere. They make me happy. I use them to quickly capture sparks of feelings and idea, to decorate otherwise boring plain-text, to categorise things like to-do tasks and time-blocks, and in my journal to write â€œemoji storiesâ€ about things that happen in my life1. For example, this emoji story is about making seafood ravioli and lasagne from scratch with my partner: ğŸŸğŸ¦ğŸ¦ªâ•ğŸ‘¨ğŸ¼â€ğŸ³ğŸ§‘ğŸ»â€ğŸ³ğŸ”œğŸğŸ¥Ÿ.

That is all to say, Iâ€™ve spent a non-trivial amount of time working out how to include emojis in things I type, and this post is the a collection of the things Iâ€™ve learnt. So, without further ado, here are some resources on how to incorporate emojis into almost everything, plus some bonus emoji opinions and trivia.

Inserting Emojis âŒ¨ï¸

First up, there are a few ways to include emojis in text that you are typing:

Shortcodes

Shortcodes are codes that allow you to â€œtypeâ€ emojis using a short version of the emoji name. For example, :smiley: for ğŸ˜ƒ.2

Shortcodes are supported in most extended markdown formats and markdown editors:

  • Available with auto-complete prompts in applications like Slack, RStudio Visual Mode and Notion.
  • Some platforms like Slack even support custom shortcode aliases and additional emojis.
  • The {emo} R package provides support for adding emojis as in-line code chunks to Rmarkdown via shortcode. E.g. ğŸ˜„ renders to ğŸ˜„.3

PRO:

  • Quick once you know the shortcodes.

CON:

  • You need to know and remember the shortcodes, or at least the start of the shortcode for applications that support auto-complete.
  • Shortcodes vary from application to application. This means shortcodes in one flavour of markdown might not render the same way or at all in a different flavour of markdown.4

Some cheatsheets for finding the application-specific shortcode for an emoji:

  • Holopodâ€™s Slack Emoji Cheatsheet
  • WebFXâ€™s Emoji Cheatsheet
  • Emojibaseâ€™s Shortcodes table

Emoji Pickers

Emoji pickers are input tools that allow you to browse and select emojis. They can include inline pop-up keyboards and search helpers, or a separate Character/Symbol dialog windows.

Your operating system will likely provide a default emoji picker tool (though they are all annoyingly given different namesâ€¦):

  • on macOS: use the shortcut CTRL + ATL + SPACE to bring up the Character Viewer
  • on iOS/iPadOS: select the emoji keyboard using Emoji Button or Globe from any text input.
  • on Windows: use the shortcut WINDOWS-KEY + . to bring up the Emoji Panel.

Emojipediaâ€™s Can I Emoji? page links to guides for emoji usage on other common devices.

Some applications also provide emoji pickers, which you can usually access via the SPECIAL CHARACTER item in the INSERT menu, and/or the associated keyboard shortcut.

  • in Rstudio Visual Mode:
    • use the catch-all shortcut âŒ˜ /emoji to bring up the emoji picker.
    • Alternatively, use the menu sequence Insert -> Special Characters -> Emojiâ€¦ to bring up an emoji picker.

PRO:

  • Use search terms to find emojis. Great for when you donâ€™t know the exact emoji you want to use, or are looking to find a suitable emoji. If you want more search results, try Emojipediaâ€™s search5.

CON:

  • Slower than shortcodes when inserting frequently used emojis.
  • The picker will usually close after you insert one emoji, so you need to open the picker repeatedly if you are inserting multiple emojis.

Copy-Paste

When all else fails you can try to copy-paste the emoji from somewhere like Emojipedia. Basically any application that supports UTF-8 encoding should display emoji characters. I donâ€™t really consider this a viable method though because it is too slow and cumbersome to use in day-to-day workflows.

Comparing Input Methods

Exactly which methods are available depends on what application or file format you are working with. Keep in mind that support for displaying or rendering emojis doesnâ€™t automatically mean it will be easy to insert emojis.

My general strategy for figuring out how to add emojis into a particular workflow is to Google â€œemojiâ€ + whichever program/markup/environment Iâ€™m working in. If youâ€™re using a tool that supports markdown, try searching the Tools directory of The Markdown Guide.

Personally, I tend to use shortcodes for frequently used and more â€œgenericâ€ emojis, but switch to an emoji picker if I want to browse, or to insert a specific version of an emoji (e.g. picking a different skin-tone).

Words of Caution âš ï¸

Of course, emojis should be used with caution. Here are a few things the internet says to keep in mind when using emojis6:

Lost in Translation

Not only do different people interpret emojis differently, they might not even be looking at the same image as you because different platforms and applications render emojis differently.

  • A New Study Shows Why You Should Be Cautious About Using Emojis at Work by Jessica Stillman for Inc.
  • How texting emojis between different devices can turn disastrous by Jessamine Molli and Daniel Hubbard for Slate. The title is more dramatic than the video, which goes through the biggest discrepancies in emoji design between Google, Apple, Microsoft, and Samsung operating systems.
  • Emoji Meanings on Emojipedia explains how their emoji experts and lexicographers write definitions for emojis taking into account things like alternative meanings around the world and cross-platform design differences.

Accessibility

Many vision impaired individuals use screen-readers to access digital content including emojis. This is something to keep in mind if you are including emojis in text intended for a broader audience, or in communication with someone you know might use a screen reader. Two important and relatively easy to implement tips Iâ€™ve come across are putting important information BEFORE any emojis, and limiting the number of emojis you use.7

  • Emojis and Accessibility: The Dos and Donâ€™ts of Including Emojis in Texts and Emails by Beth Finke

Matters of Taste

People come up with all sorts of creative ways to use emojis, and as with all things on the internet, other people have opinions. I donâ€™t agree with prescribing rules for how people use emojis so I havenâ€™t linked to anyone decrying the alleged demise of â€œproperâ€ communication due to emoji usage ğŸ™„. However, the following posts did give me some food for thought.

  • Iâ€™m a Gen Z-er and I want you to stop using emojis by Karen Ying.8
  • What happened when I stopped using Emojis by @Clo_S. An interesting experiment and reflection on deliberate and mindful usage of emojis ğŸ¤”.
